snippet: It seems unlikely that the designers of the courthouse that included statues of historical lawgivers intended offense to anyone. The intent was to instruct and inspire viewers.
abstract: New York City Public Works Dept, in perhaps eerily prescient decision, removed an eight-foot-tall marble statue of the Prophet Muhammad from the roof of the Appellate Division Courthouse in Manhattan in 1955; although move was made to facilitate a building repair, many Muslims did publicly ask for removal of the statue, and its ultimate fate has never been revealed.
lead_paragraph: It seems unlikely that the designers of the courthouse that included statues of historical lawgivers intended offense to anyone. The intent was to instruct and inspire viewers.

headline.main: A Statue of Muhammad on a New York Courthouse, Taken Down Years Ago
headline.print_headline: A Statue of Muhammad, Taken Down Years Ago
